pullRequest.body:
This lemma supports at least two use cases: Matchings in cliques and matchings with a (sub)set of universal vertices. 
In preparation for Tutte's theorem.

---

maintainer merge

Some proof simplifications, if you'd like. Nice work otherwise!

bors d+

```suggestion
    (f : s â‰ƒ t) (hadj : âˆ€ v, G.Adj v (f v)) :
```
is much weaker, right?
Fixed:) (with some slight modifications to your suggestion)

What I had in mind was the rather more symmetric
```suggestion
    (f : s â‰ƒ t) (hadj : âˆ€ v : s, G.Adj v (f v)) :
```
but your current spelling is perfectly fine

```suggestion
  have (v : V) : Decidable (v âˆˆ s) := Classical.dec _
```
in a context like this (and indeed most contexts), `haveI` and `have` do the same thing

```suggestion
  use {
    verts := s âˆª t
    Adj := fun v w â†¦ (âˆƒ h : v âˆˆ s, f âŸ¨v, hâŸ© = w) âˆ¨ (âˆƒ h : w âˆˆ s, f âŸ¨w, hâŸ© = v)
    adj_sub := by
      intro v w h
      obtain (âŸ¨hv, rflâŸ© | âŸ¨hw, rflâŸ©) := h
      Â· exact hadj âŸ¨v, _âŸ©
      Â· exact (hadj âŸ¨w, _âŸ©).symm
    edge_vert := by aesop }
```
This proof simplifies quite a bit! The two ideas here are: you use the simp lemma `dite_else_false` a couple of times to simplify the adjacency relation, which suggests that the simplified version could make a nicer definition for it. Then instead of using the axiom of choice to extract the witness (in your lines 148-151), I used the `obtain` tactic to get it instead. And `obtain` can be combined with `cases'` to make that bit even shorter. Then `aesop` does the last goal!

```suggestion
  simp only [Subgraph.IsMatching, Set.mem_union, true_and]
  intro v hv
```
Your `intro` line is unfolding the `Subgraph.IsMatching` definition, in order to use Set.mem_union. But if I ask `simp` to unfold that definition instead, then I can combine the two `simp`-calls into one (and the new proof should be a bit more robust if `Subgraph.IsMatching` changes definition, for whatever reason)

```suggestion
    simp only [hl, exists_const, true_or, exists_true_left, true_and]
    rintro y (rfl | âŸ¨hys, rflâŸ©)
    Â· rfl
    Â· exact (h.ne_of_mem hl (f âŸ¨y, hysâŸ©).coe_prop rfl).elim
```
This part also simplifies! The idea here is to use `hl` in the simp call to save the `refine` step, then again I can combine the `intro`, `cases` and `obtain` all into one. And I haven't changed your last line

```suggestion
    rintro y (âŸ¨hy, rflâŸ© | âŸ¨hy, rflâŸ©)
    Â· exact (h.ne_of_mem hy hr rfl).elim
    Â· simp
```
This one is maybe the most instructive example of how you can combine intro, cases and obtain :)
